{{about|a storm on Saturn|the storms of white clouds on Jupiter|white oval}} [[<!-- File:Saturn great white spot.gif -->File:Saturn Storm.jpg|thumb|Saturn's Great White Spot in 2011.]] [[File:Saturn Storm December 2010.jpg|thumb|The storm in December, 2010]] The '''Great White Spot''', also known as '''Great White Oval''', on [[Saturn]], named by analogy to [[Jupiter]]'s [[Great Red Spot]], are periodic storms that are large enough to be visible by telescope from Earth by their characteristic white appearance. The spots can be several thousands of kilometers wide.
The [[Cassini-Huygens|''Cassini'' orbiter]] was able to track the 2010-2011 instance of the storm,<ref name=autogenerated1>[http://www.sci-news.com/space/science-cassini-saturns-great-white-spots-02696.html Cassini Helps Solve Saturn’s Mysterious Great White Spots | Space Exploration | Sci-News.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> also known as the Northern Electrostatic Disturbance because of an increase in radio and plasma interference, or the Great Springtime Storm.<ref name="wired-2012">https://www.wired.com/2012/10/saturn-largest-hottest-vortex/</ref>
Cassini data has revealed a loss of [[acetylene]] in the white clouds, an increase of [[phosphine]], and an unusual temperature drop in the center of the storm.<ref>[http://www.skyandtelescope.com/news/122329429.html Dissecting Saturn's Big Storm] - SkyandTelescope.com</ref> After the visible aspects of the storm subsided, in 2012 a "belch" of heat and [[ethylene]] was emitted from two hotspots that merged.<ref name="wired-2012" /><ref>[http://www.cnn.com/2012/10/25/world/saturn-gas-storm/ NASA: Rare, enormous gas storm detected on Saturn - CNN.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Occurrence== The phenomenon is somewhat periodic at 28.5-year intervals, when Saturn's [[northern hemisphere]] tilts most toward the Sun. The following is a list of recorded sightings.
{{wikisourcepar|Littell's Living Age/Volume 136/Issue 1752/Bright Spot on Saturn|an account of Hall's use of the Great White Spot to calculate Saturn's rotation.}} * 1876 – Observed by [[Asaph Hall]]. He used the white spots to determine the planet's period of rotation. * 1903 – Observed by [[Edward Emerson Barnard|Edward Barnard]]. * 1933 – Observed by [[Will Hay]], comic actor and amateur astronomer. Until recent times the most celebrated observation. * 1960 – Observed by JH Botham ([[South Africa]]). * 1990 – Observed by Stuart Wilber, from 24 September through November. * 1994 – Studied by ground-based observers and the [[Hubble Space Telescope]].<ref>[http://hubblesite.org/newscenter/archive/releases/1994/53/text/ HubbleSite - NewsCenter - Hubble Observes A New Saturn Storm (12/21/1994) – Release Text]</ref> * 2006 – Observed by Erick Bondoux and Jean-Luc Dauvergne. * 2010 – First observed by Anthony Wesley,<ref>[http://news.discovery.com/space/vast-storm-rampages-across-saturn.html Vast Storm Rampages Across Saturn: Discovery News]</ref> photographed by [[Cassini space probe]] 2010-2011.<ref name=autogenerated1 />
That none were recorded before 1876 is a mystery, in some ways akin to the long observational gap of the Great Red Spot in the 18th and early 19th centuries; the 1876 Great White Spot (GWS) was extremely prominent, being visible in apertures as small as 60 mm. It is not known if the earlier record was simply poor, or if the 1876 <abbr title="Great White Spot">GWS</abbr> was truly a first for the telescopic era. Some believe that neither scenario is likely.<ref>Kidger (1992) p. 179</ref>
In 1992, Mark Kidger described three significant GWS patterns: #The GWSs alternate in latitude, with one apparition being limited to the North Temperate Zone (NTZ) or higher, and the following being limited to the Equatorial Zone (EZ). For instance, the 1960 GWS was high-latitude, and the 1990 GWS was equatorial. #The high-latitude GWSs recur at a slightly shorter interval than the equatorial GWSs (~27 versus ~30 years). #The high-latitude GWSs tend to be much less prominent than their equatorial counterparts.
Based on these apparent regularities, in 1992 Kidger forecasted (incorrectly, given the 2010-11 storm) that the next GWS would occur in the North Temperate Zone in 2016, and would probably be less spectacular than the 1990 GWS.<ref>Kidger (1992) p. 180</ref>
==Characteristics and causes== A "classic" Great White Spot is a spectacular event, in which a brilliant white storm enlivens Saturn's usually bland atmosphere; all the major ones have occurred in the planet's northern hemisphere.<ref>Kidger (1992) p. 178</ref> They typically begin as discrete, literal "spots", but then rapidly expand in [[longitude]], as the 1933 and 1990 GWSs did; in fact, the latter eventually lengthened enough to encircle the planet.<ref>Kidger (1992) p. 187-189</ref>
Though computer modeling had by the early 1990s suggested these massive atmospheric upwellings were caused by thermal instability,<ref>Kidger (1992) p. 211-212</ref> in 2015 two Caltech planetary scientists proposed a more detailed mechanism.<ref>[http://www.caltech.edu/news/explaining-saturn-s-great-white-spots-46500 Explaining Saturn’s Great White Spots | Caltech<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The theory is that as Saturn's upper atmosphere undergoes seasonal cooling, it first gets less dense as the heavier water rains out, passes a density minimum, and then gets more dense as the remaining hydrogen and helium continue to cool. Low-density upper-layer gases tend to suppress [[convection]], but high-density upper layers are unstable and cause a thunderstorm when they break into lower layers. The theory is that the storms are significantly delayed from the winter solstice due to the time it takes for the very large atmosphere to cool. The team proposes that similar storms are not seen on Jupiter because that planet has less water vapor in its upper atmosphere.
Saturn's rings block the view of the northern hemisphere from Earth during the winter solstice, so historical data on the GWS is unavailable during this season,<ref>Kidger (1992) p. 213-214</ref> but the [[Cassini space probe]] has been able to observe the whole planet since it arrived shortly after the winter solstice in 2004.<ref>[http://saturn-archive.jpl.nasa.gov/mission/introduction/ Cassini Solstice Mission: Introduction] [https://web.archive.org/web/20160525004007/https://saturn.jpl.nasa.gov/mission/about-the-mission/overview/ archive]</ref>

[[Image:HallThruster 2.jpg|thumb|2 kW Hall thruster in operation as part of the Hall Thruster Experiment at the [[Princeton Plasma Physics Laboratory]]]] In [[spacecraft propulsion]], a '''Hall-effect thruster''' ('''HET''') is a type of [[ion thruster]] in which the [[propellant]] is accelerated by an [[electric field]]. [[Hall effect|Hall-effect]] thrusters trap electrons in a [[magnetic field]] and then use the electrons to ionize propellant, efficiently accelerate the [[ion]]s to produce [[thrust]], and neutralize the ions in the plume. Hall-effect thrusters (based on the discovery by [[Edwin Hall]]) are sometimes referred to as '''Hall thrusters''' or '''Hall-current thrusters'''. Hall thrusters are often regarded as a moderate [[specific impulse]] (1,600{{nbsp}}s) [[space propulsion]] technology. The Hall-effect thruster has benefited from considerable theoretical and experimental research since the 1960s.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hofer, Richard R.|title=Development and Characterization of High-Efficiency, High-Specific Impulse Xenon Hall Thrusters|url=http://hdl.handle.net/2060/20040084644|work=NASA/CR—2004-21309|publisher=NASA STI Program|accessdate=17 October 2011}}</ref>
[[File:Xenon hall thruster.jpg|thumb|6-kW Hall thruster in operation at the [[NASA]] [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]].]]
Hall thrusters operate on a variety of propellants, the most common being [[xenon]]. Other propellants of interest include [[krypton]], [[argon]], [[bismuth]], [[iodine]], [[magnesium]], and [[zinc]].
Hall thrusters are able to accelerate their exhaust to [[effective exhaust velocity|speeds]] between 10 and 80 km/s (1,000–8,000 s [[specific impulse]]), with most models operating between 15 and 30 km/s (1,500–3,000 s specific impulse).
The thrust produced by a Hall thruster varies depending on the power level. Devices operating at 1.35 kW produce about 83 mN of thrust. High-power models have demonstrated up to 5.4 N in the laboratory.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.space.com/38444-mars-thruster-design-breaks-records.html|title=Ion Thruster Prototype Breaks Records in Tests, Could Send Humans to Mars|author=|date=|website=space.com|accessdate=27 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180320082645/https://www.space.com/38444-mars-thruster-design-breaks-records.html|archivedate=20 March 2018|df=}}</ref> Power levels up to 100 kW have been demonstrated by xenon Hall thrusters.
{{asof|2009}}, Hall-effect thrusters ranged in input [[Power (physics)|power]] levels from 1.35 to 10 kilowatts and had [[exhaust velocity|exhaust velocities]] of 10–50 kilometers per second, with [[thrust]] of 40–600 [[millinewton]]s and [[efficiency]] in the range of 45–60 percent.<ref name="Choueiri">{{Cite journal|url = |title = New Dawn for Electric Rockets|last = Choueiri|first = Edgar Y.|journal = Scientific American|accessdate = |doi = 10.1038/scientificamerican0209-58|issue = |volume = 300|pages = 58–65|date = 2009|bibcode = 2009SciAm.300b..58C}}</ref>
The applications of Hall-effect thrusters include control of the orientation and position of orbiting [[satellite]]s and use as a main propulsion engine for medium-size robotic space vehicles.<ref name="Choueiri"/>
== History == Hall thrusters were studied independently in the United States and the [[Soviet Union]]. They were first described publicly in the US in the early 1960s.<ref>{{cite conference|first1 = G.|first2 = J.|first3 = T.|last1 = Janes|last2 = Dotson|last3 = Wilson|title = Momentum transfer through magnetic fields|conference = Proceedings of third symposium on advanced propulsion concepts|volume = 2|date = 1962|location = Cincinnati, OH, USA|pages = 153–175}}</ref><ref name="Janes">{{cite conference|first1 = RG.|last1 = Meyerand|title = Momentum Transfer Through the Electric Fields|conference = Proceedings of Third Symposium on Advanced Propulsion Concepts|volume = 1|date = 1962|pages = 177–190|location = Cincinnati, OH, USA}}</ref><ref name="Seikel">{{cite conference|first1 = GR.|last1 = Seikel|title = Generation of Thrust – Electromagnetic Thrusters|conference = Proceedings of the NASA-University Conference on the Science and Technology of Space Exploration|volume = 2|date = 1962|pages = 171–176|location = Chicago, IL, USA|url = https://archive.org/stream/nasa_techdoc_19630001628/19630001628}}</ref> However, the Hall thruster was first developed into an efficient propulsion device in the Soviet Union. In the US, scientists focused instead on developing [[gridded ion thruster]]s.
Two types of Hall thrusters were developed in the Soviet Union: *thrusters with wide acceleration zone, SPT ({{lang-ru|СПД, стационарный плазменный двигатель}}; {{lang-en|SPT}}, Stationary Plasma Thruster) at [[OKB Fakel|Design Bureau Fakel]] *thrusters with narrow acceleration zone, DAS ({{lang-ru|ДАС, двигатель с анодным слоем}}; {{lang-en|TAL}}, Thruster with Anode Layer), at the [[TsNIIMash|Central Research Institute for Machine Building]] (TsNIIMASH).
[[Image:Russian stationary plasma thrusters.jpg|thumb|right|Soviet and Russian SPT thrusters]] The SPT design was largely the work of A. I. Morozov.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://fluid.ippt.gov.pl/sbarral/hall.html |title=Hall thrusters |date=2004-01-14 |accessdate= |website= |publisher= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040228215222/http://fluid.ippt.gov.pl/sbarral/hall.html |archivedate=February 28, 2004 }}</ref><ref name="Morozov_PPR">{{Cite journal|url = |title = The conceptual development of stationary plasma thrusters|last = Morozov|first = A.I.|date = March 2003|journal = Plasma Physics Reports|accessdate = |doi = 10.1134/1.1561119|pages = 235–250|publisher = Nauka/Interperiodica|bibcode = 2003PlPhR..29..235M |issue = 3|volume = 29}}</ref> The first SPT to operate in space, an SPT-50 aboard a Soviet [[Meteor (satellite)|Meteor spacecraft]], was launched December 1971. They were mainly used for satellite stabilization in North-South and in East-West directions. Since then until the late 1990s 118 SPT engines completed their mission and some 50 continued to be operated. Thrust of the first generation of SPT engines, SPT-50 and SPT-60 was 20 and 30 mN respectively. In 1982, SPT-70 and [[SPT-100]] were introduced, their thrusts being 40 and 83 mN, respectively. In the post-Soviet [[Russia]] high-power (a few [[kilowatt]]s) SPT-140, SPT-160, SPT-200, T-160 and low-power (less than 500 W) SPT-35 were introduced.<ref name="NK">{{cite web|url=http://novosti-kosmonavtiki.ru/content/numbers/198/35.shtml|title=Native Electric Propulsion Engines Today|publisher=Novosti Kosmonavtiki|date=1999|issue=7|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606033558/http://www.novosti-kosmonavtiki.ru/content/numbers/198/35.shtml|archivedate=6 June 2011|language=ru}}</ref>
Soviet and Russian TAL-type thrusters include the D-38, D-55, D-80, and D-100.<ref name="NK"/>
Soviet-built thrusters were introduced to the West in 1992 after a team of electric propulsion specialists from NASA's [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]], [[Glenn Research Center]], and the [[Air Force Research Laboratory]], under the support of the [[Ballistic Missile Defense Organization]], visited Russian laboratories and experimentally evaluated the SPT-100 (i.e., a 100 mm diameter SPT thruster). Over 200 Hall thrusters have been flown on Soviet/Russian satellites in the past thirty years. No failures have ever occurred on orbit. Hall thrusters continue to be used on Russian spacecraft and have also flown on European and American spacecraft. [[Space Systems/Loral]], an American commercial satellite manufacturer, now flies Fakel SPT-100's on their GEO communications spacecraft.
Since their introduction to the west in the early 1990s, Hall thrusters have been the subject of a large number of research efforts throughout the United States, France, Italy, Japan, and Russia (with many smaller efforts scattered in various countries across the globe). Hall thruster research in the US is conducted at several government laboratories, universities and private companies. Government and government funded centers include NASA's [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]], NASA's [[Glenn Research Center]], the [[Air Force Research Laboratory]] (Edwards AFB, CA), and [[The Aerospace Corporation]]. Universities include the [http://www.afit.edu/PA/news.cfm?article=101&a=news US Air Force Institute of Technology], [[University of Michigan]], [[Stanford University]], [[The Massachusetts Institute of Technology]], [[Princeton University]], [[Michigan Technological University]], and [[Georgia Tech]]. A considerable amount of development is being conducted in industry, such as [https://www.ihi.co.jp/en/ IHI] in Japan, [[Aerojet]] and [[Busek]] in the USA, [[SNECMA]] in France, [http://www.lajp.org.ua/ LAJP] in Ukraine, and [http://www.sitael.com/ SITAEL] in Italy.
The first use of Hall thrusters on lunar orbit was the European Space Agency (ESA) lunar mission [[SMART-1]] in 2003.
On a western satellite Hall thrusters were first demonstrated on the Naval Research Laboratory (NRL) STEX spacecraft, which flew the Russian D-55. The first American Hall thruster to fly in space was the [[Busek]] BHT-200 on [[TacSat-2]] technology demonstration spacecraft. The first flight of an American Hall thruster on an operational mission, was the [[Aerojet]] BPT-4000, which launched August 2010 on the military [[Advanced Extremely High Frequency]] GEO communications satellite. At 4.5 kW, the BPT-4000 is also the highest power Hall thruster ever flown in space. Besides the usual stationkeeping tasks, the BPT-4000 is also providing orbit raising capability to the spacecraft. Several countries worldwide continue efforts to qualify Hall thruster technology for commercial uses.
== Operation == The essential working principle of the Hall thruster is that it uses an [[electrostatic potential]] to accelerate ions up to high speeds. In a Hall thruster, the attractive negative charge is provided by an electron plasma at the open end of the thruster instead of a grid. A radial magnetic field of about 100–300 [[gauss (unit)|G]] (0.01–0.03 [[tesla (unit)|T]]) is used to confine the electrons, where the combination of the radial magnetic field and axial electric field cause the electrons to drift in azimuth thus forming the Hall current from which the device gets its name.
[[Image:Wfm hall thruster.svg|400px|thumb|Hall thruster. Hall thrusters are largely axially symmetric. This is a cross-section containing that axis.]] A schematic of a Hall thruster is shown in the adjacent image. An [[electric potential]] between 150 and 800 volts is applied between the [[anode]] and [[cathode]].
The central spike forms one pole of an [[electromagnet]] and is surrounded by an annular space, and around that is the other pole of the electromagnet, with a radial magnetic field in between.
The propellant, such as [[xenon]] gas, is fed through the anode, which has numerous small holes in it to act as a gas distributor. Xenon propellant is used because of its high [[atomic weight]] and low [[ionization potential]]. As the neutral xenon atoms diffuse into the channel of the thruster, they are ionized by collisions with circulating high-energy electrons (typically 10–40 eV, or about 10% of the discharge voltage). Once ionized, the xenon ions typically have a charge of +1, though a small fraction (~20%) have +2.
The xenon ions are then accelerated by the [[electric field]] between the anode and the cathode. For discharge voltages of 300 V, the ions reach speeds of around 15 km/s (9.3 mps) for a specific impulse of 1,500 seconds (15 kN·s/kg). Upon exiting, however, the ions pull an equal number of electrons with them, creating a [[plasma (physics)|plasma]] plume with no net charge.
The radial magnetic field is designed to be strong enough to substantially deflect the low-mass electrons, but not the high-mass ions, which have a much larger [[gyroradius]] and are hardly impeded. The majority of electrons are thus stuck orbiting in the region of high radial magnetic field near the thruster exit plane, trapped in '''E'''×'''B''' (axial electric field and radial magnetic field). This orbital rotation of the electrons is a circulating [[Hall effect|Hall current]], and it is from this that the Hall thruster gets its name. Collisions with other particles and walls, as well as plasma instabilities, allow some of the electrons to be freed from the magnetic field, and they drift towards the anode.
About 20–30% of the discharge current is an electron current, which does not produce thrust, thus limiting the energetic efficiency of the thruster; the other 70–80% of the current is in the ions. Because the majority of electrons are trapped in the Hall current, they have a long residence time inside the thruster and are able to ionize almost all of the xenon propellant, allowing mass use of 90–99%. The mass use efficiency of the thruster is thus around 90%, while the discharge current efficiency is around 70%, for a combined thruster efficiency of around 63% (= 90% × 70%). Modern Hall thrusters have achieved efficiencies as high as 75% through advanced designs.
Compared to chemical rockets, the thrust is very small, on the order of 83 mN for a typical thruster operating at 300 V, 1.5 kW. For comparison, the weight of a coin like the [[quarter (U.S. coin)|U.S. quarter]] or a 20-cent [[Euro coin]] is approximately 60 mN. As with all forms of [[electrically powered spacecraft propulsion]], thrust is limited by available power, efficiency, and [[specific impulse]].
However, Hall thrusters operate at the high [[specific impulse]]s that is typical for electric propulsion. One particular advantage of Hall thrusters, as compared to a gridded ion thruster, is that the generation and acceleration of the ions takes place in a quasi-neutral plasma, so there is no [[Space charge|Child-Langmuir charge (space charge)]] [[saturation current|saturated current]] limitation on the thrust density. This allows much smaller thrusters compared to gridded ion thrusters.
Another advantage is that these thrusters can use a wider variety of propellants supplied to the anode, even oxygen, although something easily ionized is needed at the cathode.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.permanent.com/space-transportation-electric.html#how-russ|title = Hall-Effect Stationary Plasma thrusters|date = |accessdate = 2014-06-16|website = Electric Propulsion for Inter-Orbital Vehicles|publisher = |deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130717081003/http://www.permanent.com/space-transportation-electric.html#how-russ|archivedate = 2013-07-17|df = }}[http://www.permanent.com/t-el-iov.htm#how-russ <!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071010015756/http://www.permanent.com/t-el-iov.htm |date=2007-10-10 }}</ref>
==Cylindrical Hall thrusters== Although conventional (annular) Hall thrusters are efficient in the [[kilowatt]] power regime, they become inefficient when scaled to small sizes. This is due to the difficulties associated with holding the performance scaling parameters constant while decreasing the channel size and increasing the applied [[magnetic field]] strength. This led to the design of the cylindrical Hall thruster. The cylindrical Hall thruster can be more readily scaled to smaller sizes due to its nonconventional discharge-chamber geometry and associated [[magnetic field]] profile.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Y. Raitses|author2=N. J. Fisch|title=Parametric Investigations of a Nonconventional Hall Thruster|url=http://htx.pppl.gov/publication/Journal/CHT_PoP_2001.pdf|publisher=Physics of Plasmas, 8, 2579 (2001)|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100527094903/http://htx.pppl.gov/publication/Journal/CHT_PoP_2001.pdf|archivedate=2010-05-27|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author1=A. Smirnov |author2=Y. Raitses |author3=N.J. Fisch |title=Experimental and theoretical studies of cylindrical Hall thrusters |url=http://htx.pppl.gov/publication/Journal/CHT_Artem_PoP2007.pdf |publisher=Physics of Plasmas 14, 057106 (2007) |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100527095129/http://htx.pppl.gov/publication/Journal/CHT_Artem_PoP2007.pdf |archivedate=2010-05-27 |df= }}</ref><ref name=NTRS>{{cite web|author1=Polzin, K. A. |author2=Raitses, Y. |author3=Gayoso, J. C. |author4=Fisch, N. J. |title=Comparisons in Performance of Electromagnet and Permanent-Magnet Cylindrical Hall-Effect Thrusters|url=http://hdl.handle.net/2060/20100035731|work=NASA Technical Reports Server|publisher=Marchall Space Flight Center|accessdate=17 October 2011}}</ref> The cylindrical Hall thruster more readily lends itself to miniaturization and low-power operation than a conventional (annular) Hall thruster. The primary reason for cylindrical Hall thrusters is that it is difficult to achieve a regular Hall thruster that operates over a broad envelope from ~1 kW down to ~100 W while maintaining an efficiency of 45-55%.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Polzin, K. A. |author2=Raitses, Y. |author3=Merino, E. |author4=Fisch, N. J. |title=Preliminary Results of Performance Measurements on a Cylindrical Hall-Effect Thruster with Magnetic Field Generated by Permanent Magnets|url=http://hdl.handle.net/2060/20090014067|work=NASA Technical Reports Server|publisher=Princeton Plasma Physics Laboratory|accessdate=17 October 2011}}</ref>
==External discharge Hall thruster== Sputtering erosion of discharge channel walls and pole pieces that protect the magnetic circuit causes failure of thruster operation. Therefore, annular and cylindrical Hall thrusters have limited lifetime. Although magnetic shielding has been shown to dramatically reduce discharge channel wall erosion, pole piece erosion is still a concern.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://arc.aiaa.org/doi/abs/10.2514/6.2014-3899|title=Pole-piece Interactions with the Plasma in a Magnetically Shielded Hall Thruster|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref> As an alternative, an unconventional Hall thruster design called external discharge Hall thruster or external discharge plasma thruster (XPT) has been introduced.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://arc.aiaa.org/doi/abs/10.2514/6.2016-4951|title=Preliminary Investigation of an External Discharge Plasma Thruster|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://repository.exst.jaxa.jp/dspace/bitstream/a-is/549895/1/SA6000036090.pdf|title=Numerical Investigation of an External Discharge Hall Thruster Design Utilizing Plasma-lens Magnetic Field|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170814095202/https://repository.exst.jaxa.jp/dspace/bitstream/a-is/549895/1/SA6000036090.pdf|archivedate=2017-08-14|df=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ltu.diva-portal.org/smash/record.jsf?pid=diva2%3A1037721&dswid=1358|title=Low–voltage External Discharge Plasma Thruster and Hollow Cathodes Plasma Plume Diagnostics Utilising Electrostatic Probes and Retarding Potential Analyser|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170829163334/http://ltu.diva-portal.org/smash/record.jsf?pid=diva2%3A1037721&dswid=1358|archivedate=2017-08-29|df=}}</ref> External discharge Hall thruster does not possess any discharge channel walls or pole pieces. Plasma discharge is produced and sustained completely in open space outside the thruster structure, and thus erosion free operation is achieved.
== Applications == Hall thrusters have been flying in space since December 1971 when the Soviets launched an SPT-50 on a Meteor satellite.<ref>{{cite book|last=Turner, Martin J. L. |title=Rocket and Spacecraft Propulsion: Principles, Practice and New Developments, page 197|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xBYYasVPpvAC&pg=PA197&lpg=PA197 |publisher=[[Springer Science & Business Media]] | date=5 November 2008| accessdate=28 October 2015}}</ref> Over 240 thrusters have flown in space since that time with a 100% success rate.<ref name=meyer> {{NASA |article="In-space propulsion systems roadmap." (April 2012). |url=http://www.nasa.gov/pdf/501329main_TA02-ID_rev3-NRC-wTASR.pdf |author=Meyer, Mike, et al}}</ref> Hall thrusters are now routinely flown on commercial GEO communications satellites where they are used for orbital insertion and [[Orbital station-keeping|stationkeeping]].
The first{{failed verification|date=December 2015}} Hall thruster to fly on a western satellite was a Russian D-55 built by TsNIIMASH, on the NRO's [[STEX]] spacecraft, launched on October 3, 1998.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.nro.gov/news/press/1998/1998-09.pdf |publisher=Naval Research Laboratory (Press Release) |title=National Reconnaissance Office Satellite Successfully Launched |date=October 3, 1998 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111113154021/http://nro.gov/news/press/1998/1998-09.pdf |archivedate=November 13, 2011 |df= }}</ref>
The [[solar electric propulsion]] system of the [[European Space Agency]]'s [[SMART-1]] spacecraft used a Snecma [[PPS-1350]]-G Hall thruster.<ref name="Cornu, N. 2007">{{Cite conference|doi = 10.2514/6.2007-5197|title = PPS®1350 Qualification Demonstration: 10500 hrs on the Ground and 5000 hrs in Flight|last1 = Cornu|first1 = Nicolas|first2 = Frédéric|last2 = Marchandise|last3 = Darnon|first3 = Franck|last4 = Estublier|first4 = Denis|conference = 43rd AIAA/ASME/SAE/ASEE Joint Propulsion Conference & Exhibit|location = Cincinnati, OH, USA|date = 2007}}</ref> SMART-1 was a technology demonstration mission that orbited the [[Moon]]. This use of the PPS-1350-G, starting on September 28, 2003, was the first use of a Hall thruster outside [[geosynchronous earth orbit]] (GEO). Unlike most Hall thruster propulsion systems used in commercial applications, the Hall thruster on SMART-1 could be throttled over a range of power, specific impulse, and thrust.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Ion engine gets SMART-1 to the Moon: Electric Propulsion Subsystem |url=http://www.esa.int/esaMI/SMART-1/SEMLZ36LARE_0.html#subhead2 |date=August 31, 2006 |accessdate=2011-07-25 |publisher=[[ESA]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110129072135/http://www.esa.int/esaMI/SMART-1/SEMLZ36LARE_0.html#subhead2 |archivedate=January 29, 2011 |df= }}</ref> It has a discharge power range of 0.46–1.19 kW, a [[specific impulse]] of 1,100–1,600 s and thrust of 30–70 mN.
==In development== The largest planned Hall-effect thruster is NASA's 40 kW [[Advanced Electric Propulsion System]] (AEPS), meant to propel large-scale science missions and cargo transportation in deep space.<ref name='AEPS 2017'>[https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/20180001297.pdf Overview of the Development and Mission Application of the Advanced Electric Propulsion System (AEPS)]. (PDF). Daniel A. Herman, Todd A. Tofil, Walter Santiago, Hani Kamhawi, James E. Polk, John S. Snyder, Richard R. Hofer, Frank Q. Picha, Jerry Jackson and May Allen. NASA; NASA/TM—2018-219761. 35th International Electric Propulsion Conference. Atlanta, Georgia, October 8–12, 2017. Accessed: 27 July 2018.</ref>

[[Image:Jan Hamrin.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Jan Hamrin]] '''Jan Hamrin''' has spent 30 years [[renewable energy commercialization|promoting renewable energy]] through research, policy formulation, and the development of consumer programs. She founded the non-profit [[Center for Resource Solutions]] in 1997 and retired as president of CRS at the end of 2007.<ref name=jan>[http://www.csrwire.com/News/13570.html Dr. Jan Hamrin Receives 2008 National Green Power Leadership Award As Renewable Energy Pioneer]</ref>
Hamrin has served as advisor to the [[G8|G-8]] and numerous legislatures and regulatory commissions as well as co-authoring two books: ''Affected with the Public Interest: Electric Industry Restructuring in an Era of Competition'' (1994) and ''Investing in the Future: A Regulator’s Guide to Renewables'' (1993). In 1981 Hamrin founded and served for nine years as Executive Director of the Independent Energy Producers’ Association (IEP) in California and played a key role in the implementation of the [[Public Utilities Regulatory Policies Act]] (PURPA) in California and elsewhere.<ref name=ham>[http://www.epa.gov/greenpower/documents/GPprogramv3.pdf 2002 Green Power Leadership Awards]</ref>
Jan Hamrin received her Ph.D. in Ecology, with emphasis on [[public policy]] evaluation of environmental and energy programs, from the [[University of California, Davis]]. She also holds master's degrees in Public Administration from U.C. Davis as well as a B.S. from the [[University of New Mexico]].<ref name=ham/>
In October 2008, Hamrin received a Green Power Leadership "Pioneer" award from the [[U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA)'s Green Power Partnership, and the [[U.S. Department of Energy]], for a career spent "building the market for [[green power]]".<ref name=jan/>

page.title: Louis-Élisabeth de La Vergne de Tressan

revision.text:
[[Image:Tressan.jpg|thumb|Porträt of Tressan. Engraving from [[Alexandre Desenne]], 1824]] '''Louis-Élisabeth de la Vergne, comte de Tressan''' (4 November 1705, [[Le Mans]] - 31 October 1783, from a fall from a carriage en route to [[Saint-Leu-la-Forêt]]) was a French soldier, physician, scientist, medievalist and writer, best known for his adaptations of "[[Romance (heroic literature)|romans chevaleresques]]" of the [[Middle Ages]], which contributed to the rise of the [[Troubadour style]] in the French arts.
== Biography == Aged 13, he was the companion of the young [[Louis XV]], then lieutenant-général and king's aide de camp at the [[battle of Fontenoy]]. He was made governor of [[Toul]] and was summoned by [[Stanisław Leszczyński|king Stanislas]] to his court at [[Lunéville]], where he received the title of grand marshal.
The first director of the Société Royale des Sciences et Belles-Lettres of [[Nancy, France|Nancy]] in 1751 and a member of several other academies in France and abroad, he was elected a member of the [[French academy of sciences|Académie des sciences]] in 1749 and of the [[Académie française]] in 1780.
A friend of [[Voltaire]] and [[Georges-Louis Leclerc, comte de Buffon|Buffon]], he frequented the [[salon (gathering)|salon]] of [[Claudine Guérin de Tencin|Mme de Tencin]] and composed several odes as well as adaptations of chivalric romances, which he translated and adapted from Spanish and [[Old French]], into editions which would be re-issued several times. He was also the author of one of the first treatises on electricity in French, and collaborated on volumes VI and VII of the ''[[Encyclopédie ou Dictionnaire raisonné des sciences, des arts et des métiers|Encyclopédie]]'' of [[Denis Diderot|Diderot]] and [[Jean le Rond d'Alembert|D’Alembert]].<ref>[http://www.persee.fr/web/revues/home/prescript/article/rde_0769-0886_1990_num_8_1_1057 Kafker, Frank A.: ''Notices sur les auteurs des 17 volumes de « discours » de l'Encyclopédie (suite et fin).'' Recherches sur Diderot et sur l'Encyclopédie Année (1990) Volume 8 Numéro 8 p. 117]</ref>
== Works== *''[[Amadis de Gaule]], traduction libre'' (1779) *''[[Roland furieux]]. Poème héroïque de [[Ludovico Ariosto|l’Arioste]]'' (4 volumes, 1780) *''Essai sur le fluide électrique, considéré comme agent universel'' (2 volumes, 1786). Online text : [https://web.archive.org/web/20081211070040/http://cnum.cnam.fr/SYN/8SAR1.html] *''Corps d’extraits de romans de chevalerie'' (4 volumes, 1782). Containing :: I. ''Discours préliminaire sur les romans françois. Tristan de Léonois, fils de Meliadus. Artus de Bretagne. Flores et Blanche-Fleur. Cléomades et Claremonde'' (d’après [[Adenet le Roi]]). ''Extrait du [[Roman de la Rose]], précédé d’une courte dissertation sur l’état de la littérature française sous les règnes de [[Louis VI of France|Louis VI]], [[Louis VII of France|Louis VII]], [[Philip II of France|Philippe-Auguste]], [[Louis VIII of France|Louis VIII]], [[Louis IX of France|S. Louis]], [[Philip III of France|Philippe le Hardi]] et [[Philip IV of France|Philippe le Bel]] ; extrait du commencement du Roman de la Rose et des 4150 premiers vers qui nous sont restés de [[Guillaume de Loris]]. Pierre de Provence et la Belle Maguelone.'' ::II. ''La Fleur des batailles, ou Histoire des hauts faits de Doolin de Mayence. Huon de Bordeaux. Guérin de Montglave.'' ::III. ''Dom Ursino le Navarin et Dona Inès d’Oviédo. Histoire et plaisante chronique du petit Jehan de Saintré et de la Dame des Belles-cousines'' (after [[Antoine de La Sale]]). ''Les Apparences trompeuses, extrait de l’histoire du très noble et chevaleureux prince Gérard, comte de Nevers'' (after [[Gerbert de Montreuil]]). ::IV. ''Recherches sur l’origine des romans inventés avant l’ère chrétienne. Histoire de Rigda et de Regner Lodbrog. Zélie, ou l’Ingénue''. *''Le Chevalier Robert, ou Histoire de Robert surnommé le Brave'' (1800) *''Rose Summers, ou les Dangers de l’imprévoyance traduit librement de l’anglais'' (1805) *''Œuvres'' (8 volumes, 1822–23)
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080501193359/http://www.academie-francaise.fr/immortels/base/academiciens/fiche.asp?param=259 Biography on the Académie française site]

{{Infobox power station |name = {{unbulleted list|Lungmen Nuclear Power Plant|{{zh|t=龍門核能發電廠|labels=no}} }} |image = 台湾第四原子力発電所.jpg |image_caption = |location_map = Taiwan |country = [[Republic of China|Taiwan]] |location = [[Gongliao District]] | coordinates = {{coord|25|02|19|N|121|55|27|E|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} |owner = [[Taiwan Power Company|Taipower]] |operator = Taipower |construction_began = 1999 |commissioned = {{unbulleted list|N/A (Unit 1)|N/A (Unit 2)}} |decommissioned = |np_reactor_supplier = [[General Electric]] |np_reactor_type = [[ABWR]] |ps_units_decommissioned = |ps_units_uc = 2 x 1,350 MW<ref name=wnn-20140110>{{cite news |url=http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/NN-Commissioning-approaches-for-Lungmen-1001141.html |title=Commissioning approaches for Lungmen |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date={{date|2014-01-10|mdy}} |work=World Nuclear News |accessdate={{date|2014-11-24|mdy}} }}</ref> |ps_units_planned = |ps_electrical_capacity = 2,700 [[Megawatt|MW]] |status = Halted<ref>{{cite news |url=http://sputniknews.com/voiceofrussia/news/2014_04_27/Construction-halted-at-Taiwan-nuclear-plant-after-protests-6641/ |title=Construction halted at Taiwan nuclear plant after protests |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date={{date|2014-04-27|mdy}} |work=The Voice of Russia |accessdate={{date|2014-11-24|mdy}} }}</ref> |ps_units_operational = |cost = {{unbulleted list|[[New Taiwan Dollar|NT$]]280 billion|([[United States Dollar|US$]]9.4 billion)}} |website = }}
The '''Lungmen Nuclear Power Plant''' ({{zh|c=龍門核能發電廠|p=Lóngmén Hénéng Fādiànchǎng|l=Dragon Gate Nuclear Power Plant}}) (formerly '''Gongliao Nuclear Power Plant''' and '''Fourth Nuclear Power Plant''', often abbreviated as: {{zh|t=核四|p=Hésì|l=Nuke 4}}), located nearby [[Fulong Beach]], [[Gongliao District]], [[New Taipei City]], is [[Taiwan]]'s fourth [[nuclear power plant]], consisting of two [[ABWR]]s each of 1,300 [[Megawatt|MWe]] net. It is owned by [[Taiwan Power Company]] (Taipower). It was intended to be the first of these advanced [[Generation III reactors]] built [[ABWR#Deployments|outside Japan]]. In 2014 construction of the plant was deferred.
The preceding four reactors in Japan were completed in four to five years. Taipower, however, did not award the contract as a turnkey plant, but hired General Electric to build the reactors, [[Mitsubishi Heavy Industries]] to supply the turbines and the generators, and other contractors for the rest,<ref>{{cite report |url=http://www.aec.gov.tw/english/nuclear/psar/lm_document_psar_01_04.pdf |title=Lungmen Units 1&2 Preliminary Safety Analysis Report |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |publisher=Atomic Energy Council |location=Taipei |chapter=1.4 Identification of Agents and Contractors |accessdate={{date|2014-11-25|mdy}} }}</ref> making the project very difficult to manage. In addition, the project was canceled in 2000 by the government when it was 10-30% complete,<ref name=TThalt00>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/local/archives/2000/10/28/0000058936 |title=Activists applaud killing of nuclear plant plan |author=Chiu, Yu-tzu |date={{date|2000-10-28|mdy}} |newspaper=Taipei Times |accessdate={{date|2014-11-25|mdy}} }}</ref> only to restart the following year. All these have resulted in significant cost overruns, while in 2011 the Taiwan [[Atomic Energy Council]] (AEC) criticized Taipower's management of the project.<ref name=WNA-tw>{{cite web |url=http://www.world-nuclear.org/info/Country-Profiles/Others/Nuclear-Power-in-Taiwan/ |title=Nuclear Power In Taiwan |publisher=World Nuclear Association |date=February 2013 |accessdate=28 October 2013}}</ref> The construction has been delayed by legal, regulatory and political delays.<ref name=wnn-20140801>{{cite news |url=http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/RS-Lungmen-1-passes-pre-operational-tests-0108144.html |title=Lungmen 1 passes pre-operational tests |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date={{date|2014-08-01|mdy}} |work=World Nuclear News |accessdate={{date|2014-11-24|mdy}} }}</ref> The proposed 2014 national referendum to decide the fate of the power plant<ref name=tt-20140430>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2014/04/30/2003589237 |title=NUCLEAR POWER DEBATE: Proposal for referendum on fuel rods gets support |author=Lee, I-chia |date={{date|2014-04-30|mdy}} |newspaper=Taipei Times |accessdate={{date|2014-11-24|mdy}} }}</ref> was rejected from the ballot for contradictory and confusing language, despite gathering more than 120,000 signatures.<ref name=tt-20140823>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/front/archives/2014/08/23/2003598052 |title=Committee rejects referendum proposal |author1=Loa, Iok-sin |author2=Lin, Sean |date={{date|2014-08-23|mdy}} |newspaper=Taipei Times |accessdate={{date|2014-11-24|mdy}} }}</ref> In 2018, Taipower started shipping unused fuel rods back to the [[US]]. Taipower aims to remove all fuel rods from the plant by 2020. The ruling [[Democratic Progressive Party]] plans to shut down all nuclear plants in Taiwan by 2025. The removal of the fuel rods may mean that the plant's construction will never be restarted. <ref>http://m.focustaiwan.tw/news/asoc/201809050007.aspx</ref><ref>http://m.focustaiwan.tw/news/asoc/201807040018.aspx</ref>
==History== The Fourth Nuclear Power Plant was first proposed in 1978,<ref name=Lassen00>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/feat/archives/2000/09/10/0000052791/1 |title=Power play |author1=Lassen, Jonathan |date={{date|2000-09-10|mdy}} |newspaper=Taipei Times |accessdate={{date|2014-11-25|mdy}} }}</ref> and Taipower selected the ABWR in 1996 after a competitive bidding process.<ref name=PTdg12>{{cite web |url=http://www.power-technology.com/projects/lungmen/ |title=Lungmen (Dragon Gate) Nuclear Project, Taiwan |author=<!--Staff writer(s), no by-line.--> |date=2012 |website=Power Technology |accessdate={{date|2014-11-25|mdy}} }}</ref> The reactor is designed by [[General Electric]], but is supported by [[Hitachi]], [[Shimizu Corporation]], [[Toshiba]], and other American, Taiwanese, and other Chinese and international companies.<ref>{{cite report |title=Status report 97 - Advanced Boiling Water Reactor (ABWR) |url=https://aris.iaea.org/sites/..%5CPDF%5CABWR.pdf |publisher=IAEA |accessdate=15 July 2014 |chapter=12.3 Entities involved (Taiwan, China) |quote=The Lungmen project is supported by the GE Team, including: Black & Veatch, Hitachi, Shimizu, Toshiba, and other US, Taiwan, China and international participants.}}</ref>
===Construction=== Construction of the plant began in 1999<ref>{{cite web |url=http://world-nuclear.org/NuclearDatabase/reactordetails.aspx?id=27570&rid=8C21AF2F-C273-40F3-971A-C43C114982D0&country=Taiwan |title=Lungmen-2, Taiwan |website=World Nuclear Association |year= 2013 |accessdate=29 October 2013}}</ref> and was expected to be completed in 2004. Delays in construction (some for political reasons) have increased the cost of the project. Costs have also increased from increases in the costs of raw materials from 2003.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Lee|first1=Min|title=Nuclear Energy Development in Asia Problems and Prospects|publisher=Palgrave|isbn=978-0-230-22150-5|pages=182|edition=Energy, Climate and the Environment Series}}</ref>
The [[921 earthquake]] in 1999 prompted three legislators to inspect construction progress; they cited rusty rebar and potential seawater seepage into the plant's foundation as potential issues.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/local/archives/1999/10/29/0000008580 |title=Activists ask for delay of nuke plant |author1=Chiu, Yu-tzu |date={{date|1999-10-29|mdy}} |newspaper=Taipei Times |accessdate={{date|2014-11-25|mdy}} }}</ref> [[President of the Republic of China|President]] [[Chen Shui-bian]] was elected along with other [[Democratic Progressive Party]] (DPP) legislators in March 2000 on an anti-nuclear platform which included stopping plant construction.<ref name=Lassen00 /><ref name=Chiu01>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/local/archives/2001/05/08/0000084816 |title=Construction delays condemned |author1=Chiu, Yu-tzu |date={{date|2001-05-08|mdy}} |newspaper=Taipei Times |accessdate={{date|2014-11-25|mdy}} }}</ref> DPP legislators called for a halt to the project in April 2000,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/local/archives/2000/04/09/0000031590 |title=Nuclear plant in question |author1=Chiu, Yu-tzu |date={{date|2000-04-09|mdy}} |newspaper=Taipei Times |accessdate={{date|2014-11-25|mdy}} }}</ref> which led to the suspension of construction in October 2000 by [[Premier of the Republic of China|Premier]] [[Chang Chun-hsiung]].<ref name=TThalt00 /> Contractors were idled for 111 days from 2000 October 27 to 14 February 2001. This delay caused a 576-day delay towards commercial operation.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Lee|first1=Min|title=Nuclear Energy Development in Asia Problems and Prospects|publisher=Palgrave|isbn=978-0-230-22150-5|pages=180|edition=Energy, Climate and the Environment Series}}</ref>
Taipower constructed a [[wharf]] in 2003 to accommodate delivery of heavy components, such as the reactor vessel. The wharf was beset with construction delays and may have contributed to local beach erosion, prompting further protests.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2003/05/10/0000205404 |title=Taipower wants to import a nuclear reactor in June |author1=Chiu, Yu-tzu |date={{date|2003-05-10|mdy}} |newspaper=Taipei Times |accessdate={{date|2014-11-25|mdy}} }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2003/07/03/2003057825 |title=Government considers redesigning wharf |author1=Chiu, Yu-tzu |date={{date|2003-07-03|mdy}} |newspaper=Taipei Times |accessdate={{date|2014-11-25|mdy}} }}</ref> Each reactor vessel delivery was greeted with activist protests<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2004/07/07/2003178012 |title=Activists protest Japan reactor |author1=Chiu, Yu-tzu |date={{date|2004-07-07|mdy}} |newspaper=Taipei Times |accessdate={{date|2014-11-25|mdy}} }}</ref> and construction delays resulted in the vessels being stored longer than expected, with Unit 1's reactor vessel not installed until 2005.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2005/03/16/2003246440 |title=Old reactor unit sparks concern |author1=Chiu, Yu-tzu |date={{date|2005-03-16|mdy}} |newspaper=Taipei Times |accessdate={{date|2014-11-25|mdy}} }}</ref>
Design of the plant was carried out by [[Stone & Webster]] (S&W), but Taipower canceled its contract with S&W in 2007, leading to protracted litigation from 2007 to 2011.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2011/03/10/2003497827 |title=Taipower must pay US$29m: court |author1=Tang, Chia-ling |date={{date|2011-03-10|mdy}} |newspaper=Taipei Times |accessdate={{date|2014-11-25|mdy}} }}</ref>
In 2010, aboriginal artifacts were found at the construction site, prompting calls to halt construction again.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2010/04/28/2003471695 |title=Aboriginal artifacts found at site of nuclear plant |author1=Huang, Shelley |date={{date|2010-04-28|mdy}} |newspaper=Taipei Times |accessdate={{date|2014-11-25|mdy}} }}</ref>
Taipower was fined by the AEC twice, in 2008 and 2011, for completing design changes without first obtaining approval from the plant's designer, General Electric.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2011/11/08/2003517784 |title=Taipower fined by AEC NT$15 million |author1=Lee, I-chia |date={{date|2011-11-08|mdy}} |newspaper=Taipei Times |accessdate={{date|2014-11-25|mdy}} }}</ref><ref>{{cite techreport |url=http://www.aec.gov.tw/english/nuclear/files/2012-01.pdf |title=Overview of Recent Regulatory Activities in Taiwan |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |publisher=Atomic Energy Council, Department of Nuclear Regulation |page=27 |date={{date|2012-05-19|mdy}} |accessdate={{date|2014-12-04|mdy}} }}</ref> Taipower later stated the changes were executed to stay on schedule, and approval was later obtained from GE for 97% of the changes.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2014/01/21/2003581790 |title=Taipower mulling filing an appeal |author1=Lee, I-chia |date={{date|2014-01-21|mdy}} |newspaper=Taipei Times |accessdate={{date|2014-11-25|mdy}} }}</ref>
The temporary cancellation by the Government and other project management difficulties caused significant delays, pushing the price tag of the plant to more than US$7.5 billion in 2009.<ref name=PTdg12 /> {{as of|2014}}, the total price tag was close to US$10 billion, or NT$300 billion.<ref name=wnn-20140801 /><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/front/archives/2014/04/26/2003588911 |title=Ma and Su discuss nuclear plant, remain far apart |author1=Shih Hsiu-chuan |date={{date|2014-04-26|mdy}} |newspaper=Taipei Times |accessdate={{date|2014-11-25|mdy}} }}</ref>
In August 2014, the plant completed its safety tests required before operation can begin. 126 systems were tested including cooling, shutdown, containment, control and power generation. [[Ministry of Economic Affairs (Taiwan)|Minister of Economic Affairs]] [[Chang Chia-juch]] said, "Passing the rigorous review illustrates the high standards of care invested in the design and construction of the facility." The reactor will be closed until the status is decided by referendum. In the meantime, the reactor costs 1.3 billion NT Dollars a year to maintain in a mothballed state.<ref name=wnn-20140801 /> [[File:Nuclear Power Plant Lungmen.jpg|thumb|left|Construction of Lungmen Nuclear Power Plant]]
===2013 and 2014 referendums=== Environmental groups called for a [[Referendums in the Republic of China|national referendum]] in April 2011, following the [[Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2011/04/12/2003500553 |title=Groups call for nuclear referendum |author=Chang, Rich |newspaper=Taipei Times |date={{date|2011-04-12|mdy}} |accessdate={{date|2014-11-25|mdy}} }}</ref> By obtaining the signatures of a certain percentage of registered voters, or by legislative action, a referendum may be referred to the national ballot for voter action. However, due to the politically sensitive nature of the Fourth Nuclear Plant issue, legislatively-referred and voter-referred referendums have failed to enter the national ballot.
Because of the controversy over the plant, in February 2013 the [[Kuomintang]] (KMT)-led government proposed that a referendum should be issued, which would allow the people of the country to decide the fate of the plant.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/front/archives/2013/02/26/2003555734 |title=Nuclear referendum receives go-ahead |author=Shih, Hsiu-chuan |newspaper=Taipei Times |date={{date|2013-02-26|mdy}} |accessdate={{date|2014-11-25|mdy}} }}</ref> The proposed referendum was sponsored by 32 KMT lawmakers led by Lee Ching-hua<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2013/04/20/2003560199 |title=Nuclear referendum question protested |author=Lee, I-chia |newspaper=Taipei Times |date={{date|2013-04-20|mdy}} |accessdate={{date|2014-11-25|mdy}} }}</ref> and asked "Do you agree that the construction of the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant should be halted and that it not become operational?"<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/front/archives/2013/03/08/2003556550 |title=KMT unveils text of nuclear referendum |author=Shih, Hsiu-chuan |newspaper=Taipei Times |date={{date|2013-03-08|mdy}} |accessdate={{date|2014-11-25|mdy}} }}</ref> Referendums must have good voter turnout (greater than 50% of registered voters must participate in the referendum vote), and a majority of participating voters must vote yes in order for the referendum to become binding, meaning that poor voter turnout would ensure referendum defeat (and in the case of the Lee referendum, continued construction).<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2013/03/09/2003556653 |title=Nuclear Power Debate: Academics slam referendum question |author=Shan, Shelley |newspaper=Taipei Times |date={{date|2013-03-09|mdy}} |accessdate={{date|2014-11-25|mdy}} }}</ref> The opposition DPP claimed that getting better than 50% voter turnout in a non-Presidential election year was too difficult, and barricaded the legislative chamber to prevent a vote to place the Lee referendum on the national ballot. This led to [[Legislative violence#Taiwan|a scuffle]] when KMT legislators attempted to break through the barricade, and the Lee referendum was not voted on.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/NP-Taiwanese_nuclear_vote_turns_violent-0208135.html |title=Taiwanese Nuclear Vote Turns Violent |work=World Nuclear News |date={{date|2013-08-02|mdy}} |accessdate={{date|2013-10-29|mdy}} }}</ref> In the following legislative session, protesters called on the government to withdraw the Lee referendum,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2013/09/18/2003572423 |title=Activists want no referendum and no nuclear plant |author=Lee, I-chia |newspaper=Taipei Times |date={{date|2013-09-18|mdy}} |accessdate={{date|2014-11-25|mdy}} }}</ref> and it was subsequently withdrawn.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/front/archives/2013/09/11/2003571849 |title=KMT's Lee withdraws nuclear poll proposal |author1=Shih, Hsiu-chuan |author2=Wang, Chris |newspaper=Taipei Times |date={{date|2013-09-11|mdy}} |accessdate={{date|2014-11-25|mdy}} }}</ref>
[[Annette Lu]] used the local referendum process to debate the plant's fate as early as 2012.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2012/07/18/2003538044 |title=Lu launches bid for nuclear referendum |author=Wang, Chris |newspaper=Taipei Times |date={{date|2012-07-18|mdy}} |accessdate={{date|2014-11-26|mdy}} }}</ref> Her petition for a local referendum gathered 50,000 signatures by March 2013,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.chinapost.com.tw/taiwan/national/national-news/2013/03/12/372794/Ex-Vice-President.htm |title=Ex-Vice President Annette Lu delivers referendum petition in New Taipei |author=Li, Lauly |newspaper=The China Post |date={{date|2013-03-12|mdy}} |location=Taipei |accessdate={{date|2014-11-26|mdy}} }}</ref> but the proposed referendum was rejected by the Executive Yuan Referendum Review Committee in May 2013, ruling the issue was of national importance, and could not be decided by local referendum.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2013/05/26/2003563212 |title=Annette Lu moots another nuclear referendum bid |author=Wang, Chris |newspaper=Taipei Times |date={{date|2013-05-26|mdy}} |accessdate={{date|2014-11-26|mdy}} }}</ref> She launched another local referendum in June 2013<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2013/06/07/2003564188 |title=Lu launches new petition for nuclear referendum |author=Mo, Yan-chih |newspaper=Taipei Times |date={{date|2013-06-07|mdy}} |accessdate={{date|2014-11-25|mdy}} }}</ref> in opposition to the KMT-authored Lee referendum. Meanwhile, Lu filed suit in 2014 in the Taipei High Administrative Court over the Executive Yuan's rejection of the earlier referendum.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2014/01/23/2003581942 |title=Annette Lu files injunction over rejected nuclear poll |author=Wang, Chris |newspaper=Taipei Times |date={{date|2014-01-23|mdy}} |accessdate={{date|2014-11-26|mdy}} }}</ref> The court's decision is expected in August 2014.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2014/07/16/2003595238 |title=Annette Lu vows pursuit of anti-plant referendum |author=Wang, Chris |newspaper=Taipei Times |date={{date|2014-07-16|mdy}} |accessdate={{date|2014-11-26|mdy}} }}</ref>
A competing referendum was launched in 2012 by [[National Taiwan University]] professor [[Kao Cheng-yan]], initially as a local referendum<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2012/07/10/2003537394 |title=Anti-nuclear-group plans rock fest signature drive |author=Lee, I-chia |newspaper=Taipei Times |date={{date|2012-07-10|mdy}} |accessdate={{date|2014-11-26|mdy}} }}</ref> and then a national one in July 2014, once sufficient signatures had been gathered.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://focustaiwan.tw/news/aipl/201407150037.aspx |title=Referendum on fourth nuclear plant passes initial threshold |author1=Tang, Pei-chun |author2=Su, Justine |author3=Wu, Lilian |newspaper=Focus Taiwan News Channel |date={{date|2014-07-15|mdy}} |accessdate={{date|2014-11-26|mdy}} }}</ref> The language of the Kao referendum was formulated to require positive action: "Do you agree to allow Taiwan Power Co to insert fuel rods into the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant in New Taipei City for a test run" so poor voter turnout would result in referendum defeat, and thus create binding opposition to starting the plant.<ref name=tt-20140430 />
In April 2014, the government decided to halt construction. The first reactor was sealed after the completion of safety checks, and construction of the second reactor was halted. A final decision on whether to proceed with construction would be subject to another referendum.<ref name=reuters-20140428>{{cite news |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2014/04/27/taiwan-nuclear-idUKL3N0NJ08C20140427 |title=Taiwan to halt construction of fourth nuclear power plant |work=Reuters(UK) |agency=Reuters |date=28 April 2014 |accessdate=28 April 2014}}</ref> The ruling KMT stated the purpose of a new referendum was to have the people decide the plant's fate while weighing the consequences of not bringing a major power source on-line.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2014/04/23/2003588689 |title=Nuclear plant ‘must be seen in context’ |author=Hsiao, Alison |newspaper=Taipei Times |date={{date|2014-04-23|mdy}} |accessdate={{date|2014-11-25|mdy}} }}</ref> Electricity prices are estimated to rise by 14–40%, and electricity rationing could be imposed as early as 2021.<ref name=TT20140429>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2014/04/29/2003589160 |title=NUCLEAR POWER DEBATE: Scrapping plant would ruin Taipower: Duh |author=Lee, I-chia |newspaper=Taipei Times |date=29 April 2014 |accessdate=5 March 2015 }}</ref> Completely cancelling the plant would force Taipower to book the construction budget as a total loss and force it into insolvency.<ref name=TT20140429 />
Meanwhile, also in April 2014, the opposition DPP planned to introduce special legislation to bypass the provisions of the Referendum Act, allowing a simple majority vote (with no threshold of participation) to decide the plant's fate.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2014/04/17/2003588237 |title=DPP plans new law to resolve nuclear dispute |author=Wang, Chris |newspaper=Taipei Times |date=17 April 2014 |accessdate=5 March 2015 }}</ref> Premier [[Jiang Yi-huah]] cited the prior 2000 precedent when construction was interrupted by executive order which was later ruled unconstitutional<ref name=TT20140422>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/front/archives/2014/04/22/2003588590 |title=Jiang rejects DPP nuclear statute |author=Wang, Chris |newspaper=Taipei Times |date=22 April 2014 |accessdate=5 March 2015 }}</ref> as the reason why he rejected the proposed special legislation. The Executive Yuan stated the plant could start operations if the referendum on halting construction was not held, assuming safety tests were passed first.<ref name=TT20140422 /> Former DPP chairman [[Lin Yi-hsiung]] went on a hunger strike for two weeks to oppose continued construction,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/front/archives/2014/05/01/2003589291 |title=Lin ends anti-nuclear hunger strike |author1=Wang, Chris |author2=Lee, I-chia |newspaper=Taipei Times |date=1 May 2014 |accessdate=5 March 2015 }}</ref> reflecting a popular poll, which favored lowering the threshold of participation and opposed continued construction.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2014/04/30/2003589235 |title=NUCLEAR POWER DEBATE: Majority wants no plebiscite threshold |author=Wang, Chris |newspaper=Taipei Times |date=30 April 2014 |accessdate=5 March 2015 }}</ref>
The proposed Kao referendum was rejected by the Executive Yuan Referendum Review Committee in August 2014, citing the language as confusing and contradictory, since the reason given for the referendum is in opposition to nuclear power, while the referendum itself asks to start a nuclear reactor.<ref name=tt-20140823 /> Undaunted, supporters of the Kao referendum vowed in October 2014 to initiate another referendum.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2014/10/17/2003602286 |title=Groups plan second referendum |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |agency=CNA |date={{date|2014-10-17|mdy}} |newspaper=Taipei Times |accessdate={{date|2014-11-24|mdy}} }}</ref>
Past polls in Taiwan have showed more support for nuclear power among educated than uneducated people. The China Times poll taken in 2000 showed 60% support among those with higher degrees, and only 40% among those with only primary education.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Lee|first1=Min|title=Nuclear Energy Development in Asia Problems and Prospects|publisher=Palgrave|isbn=978-0-230-22150-5|pages=183|edition=Energy, Climate and the Environment Series}}</ref>
===Proposed 3 year construction deferment===
The Ministry of Economic Affairs proposed in August 2014 that construction be halted for three years until a national referendum could be held,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/biz/archives/2014/08/01/2003596370 |title=MOEA unveils three-year nuclear power plant plan |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=1 August 2014 |newspaper=Taipei Times |accessdate=5 March 2015 }}</ref> with Taipower estimating the three-year cost of sealing Unit 1 as less than {{dollarsign|TWD|lk=on}}2 billion.
In September 2014 Taiwan Power Co. submitted its plan to the Atomic Energy Council (AEC) to mothball Unit 1 and halt construction on Unit 2 of the No. 4 nuclear power plant for three years, beginning in 2015.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://english.kyodonews.jp/news/2014/12/327432.html |title=Taiwan ready to defer construction of new nuclear power plant |author=Ko, Shu-ling |date=15 December 2014 |publisher=Kyodo News |accessdate=5 March 2015 }}</ref> The plan, written in accordance with the April 2014 government directive to halt construction, underwent several revisions until its final submission in January 2015; the AEC approved Taipower's final plan in February, and it will take effect in July 2015 and run through 2017.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/front/archives/2015/02/04/2003610768 |title=AEC approves plan to shutter fourth nuclear facility |author=Lin, Sean |date=4 February 2015 |newspaper=Taipei Times |accessdate=5 March 2015 }}</ref> Of the 126 systems which passed safety testing, 80 will remain in operation, 14 require periodic testing to ensure they can support their safety functions and 32 will be kept in low-humidity storage.
In September 2015 GE started [[International Court of Arbitration]] proceedings over withheld payments.<ref name=wnn-20151214>{{cite news |url=http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/C-GE-seeks-arbitration-over-Lungmen-payments-1412154.html |title=GE seeks arbitration over Lungmen payments |publisher=World Nuclear News |date=14 December 2015 |accessdate=1 November 2016}}</ref>
==Safety== A Generation III nuclear reactor has a 72-hour capability of passive cooling to prevent damage to its core should the plant face a total blackout after an emergency shut down. If core overheating and meltdown became unavoidable, these reactors have core catchers that will trap the molten fuel and stop the nuclear reaction (although Lungmen, as other ABWR does not have a core catcher but rely on passive cooling of the corium<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aec.gov.tw/english/nuclear/psar/lm_document_psar_19_04.pdf |title=Preliminary Safety Analysis Report, Assessment of Severe Accident Mitigation}}</ref>). Finally, a tight containment ensures that no evacuation zone is required around a Generation III nuclear power plant.
The ABWR was designed to a 0.3G earthquake acceleration standard with the Lungmen units seismic hardening increased to 0.4G.
===Reliability=== Some custom made power plants have lower reliability in the first few years of operation. Some parts may prove unsuitable and need replacement or modifications may be necessary. ABWR uses standardized parts to avoid this, but the 3rd and 4th units displayed low reliability (45% - 70%). It is believed this experience provided knowledge that will give better results in future units. The first two units built, [[Kashiwazaki-Kariwa Nuclear Power Plant|Kashiwazaki Kariwa]] 6<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.world-nuclear.org/reactor/default.aspx/KASHIWAZAKI%20KARIWA-6|title=Kashiwazaki Kariwa-6, Japan |website=World Nuclear Association |year=2017 |accessdate=19 February 2017}}</ref> & 7<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.world-nuclear.org/reactor/default.aspx/KASHIWAZAKI%20KARIWA-7 |title=Kashiwazaki Kariwa-7, Japan |website=World Nuclear Association |year=2017 |accessdate=19 February 2017}}</ref> fared much better than the following two, [[Hamaoka Nuclear Power Plant|Hamaoka]] 5<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.world-nuclear.org/reactor/default.aspx/HAMAOKA-5 |title=Hamaoka-5, Japan |website=World Nuclear Association |year=2017 |accessdate=19 February 2017}}</ref> and [[Shika Nuclear Power Plant|Shika]] 2.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.world-nuclear.org/reactor/default.aspx/SHIKA-2 |title=Shika-2, Japan |website=World Nuclear Association |year=2017 |accessdate=19 February 2017}}</ref>

The meme can be thoughts, concepts, ideas, theories, opinions, beliefs, practices, habits, songs, or icons. Distortions of [[corporate logo]]s are also referred to as [[subvertising]].<ref>See also [[Stephen Downes]], [http://www.downes.ca/post/341 Hacking Memes] (First Monday, volume 4, issue 11) for a detailed description of meme hacks.</ref> Another definition is: "Intentionally altering a concept or phrase, or using it in a different context, so as to subvert the meaning."<ref>[http://www.samizdata.net/blog/glossary_archives/002144.html downloaded 21/11/12] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120727235926/http://www.samizdata.net/blog/glossary_archives/002144.html |date=2012-07-27 }} from [[Samizdata]]</ref>

Its principal use is as a [[dye]], but it has also been investigated for anticancer and microbial uses.
== Preparation == Morindone is obtained from the root bark of ''M. tinctoria'' or related species in two stages. In the first step, small roots of immature plants are boiled in alcohol to obtain [[morindin]], a yellowish substance which can also be used in dyeing. Further heating brings about [[hydrolysis]] of two [[glucose]] [[monomer]]s through [[Sublimation (chemistry)|sublimation]], leaving intensely red crystals.
''M. tinctoria'' is extensively grown in [[India]] for commercial production. Moridin content in the roots peaks in two to three years and drops off considerably after that; some attempts have been made to speed up production using tissue cultures.
==Use as a dye== Morindone requires a [[mordant]], and the color obtained varies depending on the substance used. Aluminum mordants give a red color, while iron and chromium produce duskier shades. The traditional mordant used in Java, jirak bark (''[[Symplocos fasciculata]]''), is rich in aluminum salts.
Compared to modern dyestuffs, morindone is not as fast or as stable. Since it can be readily cultivated, however, interest in it remains high. Recent research has examined cell culture as a means of increasing yields.

XVI |location= London|pages= 189| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MfQ4AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA189&lpg=PA189&dq=morindone#PPP11,M1| accessdate=2008-12-27}} Note that the chemical formula given here is incorrect; this reference was used only for physical properties and preparation of substance. *{{cite journal |last= Aobchey |first= Paitoon |author2=Supawadee Sriyam |author3=Worawit Praharnripoorab |author4=Sorasak Lhieochaiphant |author5=Suree Phutrakul|date=January–April 2002|title= Production of Red Pigment from the Root of ''Morinda angustifolia'' Roxb. var. ''scabridula'' Craib. by Root Cell Culture| journal= Chiang Mai University Journal |volume= 1|issue= 1 |pages=66–78|url=http://cmuj.chiangmai.ac.th/full/2002/jan2002-5f.pdf |accessdate=2009-01-05 }} *{{cite web|url=http://www.worldagroforestrycentre.org/sea/products/AFDbases/AF/asp/SpeciesInfo.asp?SpID=18062| title=Morinda citrifolia|publisher=World Agroforestry Centre|accessdate = 2009-01-05}}

'''Northern Electricity Distribution Company''' ('''NEDCO''') is an electricity distribution utility company in [[Ghana]].<ref name=iounhj/> The company is a subsidiary of the [[Volta River Authority]], the main electricity generation company in the country.<ref name=iounhj>{{cite web|title=New Electricity Company Launched In Northern Region|url=http://northernghana.com/news/i/?n=2353|publisher=northernghana.com|accessdate=26 August 2013}}</ref> The company is the sole supplier of electricity to the three Northern Regions of Ghana: [[Northern Region (Ghana)|Northern Region]], [[Upper East Region]] and [[Upper West Region]] and part of the Asante and Volta Regions. The [[Electricity Company of Ghana]] supplies the other regions.<ref name="oijo">{{cite web | url=http://www.nedco.com.gh/news.php | title=NEWS | publisher=nedco.com.gh | accessdate=26 August 2013}}</ref>
==History== NEDCO was established in 2005 as part of the [[government of Ghana]]'s policy to reform the country's energy sector. The policy also gave birth to [[Ghana Grid Company]] in 2008.<ref name=iounhj/>
==Operational footprint== The operations of NEDCO cover over sixty percent of the total land area of Ghana. Its operations extend into the northern parts of [[Volta Region]] and [[Ashanti Region]]. It also supplies power to [[Dapaong]] in [[Togo]], as well as the border towns of [[Po, Burkina Faso|Po]], [[Leo, Burkina Faso|Leo]] and [[Yuoga]] in [[Burkina Faso]].<ref name="oiujoj">{{cite web | url=http://thechronicle.com.gh/vranedco-board-inaugurated/ | title=VRA/NEDCo board inaugurated | publisher=thechronicle.com.gh | accessdate=26 August 2013}}</ref>
